title: What I Appreciate Most About The Expanded Lore And Universe
body:
It's made it a thousand times easier for fanfiction writers, such as myself, to create more realized, in depth stories. 

Being the huge D&D enthusiast that I am, I find immense joy in creating my own original characters in some of my favorite video game universes, don't worry though, I've steered as far as possible from the ever so common "sexy, misunderstood, half-angel half-demon hybrid." (Honestly, that character is so, and I cannot stress the so in this sentence enough, so common.)  

In the earlier days of League, we were given only the most basic of information about the locations and factions that made up Runeterra, as well as the cultures and people that made it, that every group could be summed up with three words or less. The Demacians were the "good guys" the Noxians were the "bad guys" everything was so clear cut and lacked any depth, making it near impossible to create an original character without them being the most boring one dimensional character ever written. This has changed a thousand times over, thanks to Riot's incredible writing and worldbuilding teams. 

Now, we're given an in-depth, interactive map of Runeterra, with the names of the most famous capitols, to even the lowliest villages, as well as perfect descriptions of the cultures and people of each faction. We can now get a better idea of the average, every day life of a person from each faction. We're given entire stories worth of history, and multiple short stories that help even further to describe life on Runeterra.  

I've created multiple characters already. A Demacian peasant boy, who, after discovering his magical talent, moves to Noxus after being promised safe haven and acceptance, while struggling to accept the brutality of the nation. A Zaunite girl who despises the technology that makes the city after witnessing her parents become little else but mindless machines due to the constant augmentations that they needed to in order to work, and now wishes only to sail across the seas. There are so many others that I've created, and it's all thanks to the wonderful writing of Riot. Without their worldbuilding, none of my creations would have been possible.

This makes me happy.
{{sticker:sg-ahri-2}} 
What sort of things would help you even more, do you think?  
No promises, just checking for unexpected ideas that we've not considered yet.

More depth into the religions or belief systems would be a start. We have some folklore that’s universally shared (Kindred) and we have Illaoi’s religion, but we don’t know much about major religions in factions like Demacia. 

We know of philosophies, and stories that support them, but those stories feel more historical to outsiders than tales you’d see in a religious book (though I know religious books can touch on real world events).

At the very least we know Noxus has, if not outright worship, at least a spiritual connection with the wolf-aspect of kindred.  Matches with the Noxian mentality of never just laying down to die.  We have seen it twice now, once in the Pillars of Strenght short story, and more recently with Vlads.

Considering how Noxus is not only meant to be highly inclusive, but also at this point has absorbed various cultures, I feel like Noxus probably has no official state religion, instead everyone practices their spirituality however they feel/prefer.  Reverence to the Wolf is probably the closest they come, and I doubt its mandated

Demacia, having an official state religion and possibly an accompanying rigid church structure would not surprise me.  Depending on how far Riot takes the "anti-magic" dogma...we could even be looking at full on witch trials.  Twist being of course with actual magic users

This. More in-depth explanations on societal and governmental structures would be helpful, too. We know very little about how Demacia’s government, military, and castes are structured, for example. Fiora’s lore hints at some degree of patriarchalism, but how deep does that go? Is it uncommon or perhaps even frowned down upon for women to become knights?

Sorry for late reply, got busy, but I agree with what Valor Bot said. I love studying theology, and that's one of the few things that are missing from the lore, the religious beliefs of the nations. So far, we only have Illaoi's god, not even going to attempt to type their name, who is worshipped by the people of the Blue Flame Isles, and most of Bilgewater, Kindred, who's present everywhere, and that's about it. I'd love more info about the cult in Zaun that worships Victor and the "Glorious Evolution" , more about the people who worship and believe in Janna, as well as more info on the "Great Spirit of Ionia".

Details!

1) Description of economies, political systems, and militaries.  Foreign policy determines the shape and direction of the world.

2) Descripton of power players and political factions.  Domestic policy determines the nature and quality of life.

3) Description of geography. A contour map of Runeterra, with the habitats vegetation and wildlife and the climate, would enable proper setting.

4) Culture.  The fine, performing, popular, and traditional art forms of every region are needed to understand its people.

An old Demacian dude sitting under a tree looking at a lightning strike over the mountains and cursing under his breath: "these damn mages and their blasted spells. back in my days we use beat the magic out of them"

{{champion:74}} Ahem...

Science works on any system that obeys laws and can be measured.  Call it nature, the universe, gods—all you need to know is that it follows rules and gives data.

Through science, we discover models that apply principles to data collected from such a system to predict how it behaves, and develop theories that satisfy our desire for an intuition about its behavior.  Any supernatural meddling with an otherwise natural system would merely be a change to its initial conditions—everything afterward would be entirely predicted by the model.

Should the divine intervention be pervasive and consistent enough, it could even be used to characterize a regime in which an adjusted model would be needed.  And to predict the godly acts, we would turn to psychology, trying to understand the being’s intentions; and turn theology into an empirical and rigorous field in order to understand the god itself.

Science interprets the supernatural as interference like the internet interprets censorship as damage: both route around it.
